Among them is one who can be cast into doubt by the slightest speech and can be drawn away from his belief by the slightest enticement or intimidation, even though he is not doubting in his conviction like the first, but they differ in the intensity of resolve. This exists in true belief as well. And action [al-'amal] affects the growth of this resolve and its increase, just as watering affects the growth of trees. Therefore, Allah, the Exalted, said: "So it increased them in faith [iman]" (9:124). And He, the Exalted, said: "That they may increase in faith [iman] with their [present] faith [iman]" (48:4). And He, glory to Him, said in what is narrated in some reports: "Faith [iman] increases and decreases." This is due to the effect of acts of obedience on the heart [al-qalb]. This is not perceived except by one who observes the states of his soul [nafs] during times of diligence in worship and devotion to it with presence of heart [al-qalb], compared to times of laxity, and perceives the disparity in the tranquility towards the beliefs of faith [iman] in these states, until his knot increases in tenacity against one who wishes to untie it through casting doubt. Indeed, one who believes in the meaning of mercy for the orphan, if he acts according to his belief by stroking his head and being gentle with him, perceives from his inner self a confirmation and multiplication of mercy due to the action [al-'amal]. Likewise, one who believes in humility, if he acts according to it by performing an act of bowing or prostrating to another, feels humility in his heart [al-qalb] upon undertaking the service. And thus all attributes of the heart [al-qalb] issue actions from the limbs, then the effect of the actions returns upon them, confirming and increasing them. This will come in the Quarter of the Deliverers and the Destroyers, upon explaining the manner of the connection of the inward [al-batin] to the outward [al-zahir], and actions [al-a'mal] to beliefs [al-'aqa'id] and hearts [al-qulub]. For that is of the kind of connection of the visible dominion [al-mulk] to the unseen dominion [al-malakut]. And I mean by the visible dominion [al-mulk] the world of witnessing [al-shahadah] perceived by the senses, and by the unseen dominion [al-malakut] the world of the unseen [al-ghayb] perceived by the light [al-nur] of insight [al-basirah]. And the heart [al-qalb] is from the world of the unseen dominion [al-malakut], and the limbs and their actions are from the world of the visible dominion [al-mulk]. The subtlety and precision of the connection between the two worlds reached a point where some people thought one was united with the other, and others thought there is no world except the world of witnessing [al-shahadah], which is these tangible bodies. Whoever perceived both matters and perceived their multiplicity, then their connection, expressed it by saying: The glass thinned and the wine thinned, And they resembled each other, so the matter became alike. As if there is wine and no goblet, And as if there is a goblet and no wine. Let us return to the intended purpose, for this knowledge is outside the knowledge of transaction [al-mu'amalah]. But between the two knowledges there is also connection and linkage. Therefore, you see the sciences of unveiling [al-mukashafah] climbing every hour upon the sciences of transaction [al-mu'amalah] until they are unveiled from them through the obligation [al-taklif]. So this is the aspect of the increase of faith [iman] through obedience, according to this application.

a.g: But as for those in whose hearts is disease, it has [only] increased them in evil [in addition] to their evil. And they will have died while they are disbelievers.
Do they not see that they are tried every year once or twice but then they do not repent nor do they remember?
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وقال تعالى: "أو لا يرون أنهم يفتنون في كل عام مرة أو مرتين ثم لا يتوبون ولا هم يذكرون" قيل يفتنون بأمراض يختبرون بها. ويقال: إن العبد إذا مرض مرضتين ثم لم يتب قال له ملك الموت: يا غافل جاءك مني رسول بعد رسول فلم تجب. وقد كان السلف لذلك يستوحشون إذا خرج عام ولم يصابوا فيه بنقص في نفس أو مال.
Indeed, do they not see that they are tested [yuftanun] in every year once or twice, then they do not repent, nor do they remember? It is said: They are tested with illnesses by which they are examined. And it is said: Indeed, when the servant [al-'abd] is afflicted with two illnesses and then does not repent, the Angel of Death [malak al-mawt] says to him: O heedless one [ya ghaafil], a messenger from me came to you, then another messenger, yet you did not respond. And for this reason, the predecessors [al-salaf] would feel desolate if a year passed and they were not afflicted with a loss in their soul [nafs] or wealth [mal].

a.g: And whenever a surah is revealed, they look at each other, [saying], "Does anyone see you?" and then they dismiss themselves. Allah has dismissed their hearts because they are a people who do not understand.
There has certainly come to you a Messenger from among yourselves. Grievous to him is what you suffer; [he is] concerned over you and to the believers is kind and merciful.
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وأما القراءة فيستحب له قراءة جملة من الآيات وردت الأخبار بفضلها وهو أن يقرأ سورة الحمد وآية الكرسي وخاتمة البقرة من قوله آمن الرسول وشهد الله وقل اللهم مالك الملك الآيتين وقوله تعالى: ﴿ لقد جاءكم رسول من أنفسكم ﴾ إلى آخرها.
And as for the recitation, it is recommended for him to recite a collection of verses for which reports have come regarding their merit. And it is that he recites the Opening Surah [al-Fatihah] and the Throne Verse [Ayat al-Kursi] and the closing of the Cow [Surah al-Baqarah] from His saying, "The Messenger has believed..." [2:285] and "Allah bears witness..." [2:286] and say, "O Allah, Owner of Sovereignty..." [3:26] — these two verses — and His saying, the Most High: "There has certainly come to you a Messenger from among yourselves..." [9:128] to its end.

a.g: But if they turn away, [O Muhammad], say, "Sufficient for me is Allah; there is no deity except Him. On Him I have relied, and He is the Lord of the Great Throne."
a.ihya:
Tafsir Al-Ihya
وقد روي عن أبي الدرداء أنه قال: من قال في كل يوم سبع مرات فإن تولوا فقل حسبى الله لا إله إلا هو عليه توكلت وهو رب العرش العظيم كفاه الله عز وجل ما أهمه من أمر آخرته صادقا كان أو كاذبا.
Indeed, it has been narrated from Abu al-Darda' that he said: Whoever says seven times each day, "So if they turn away, then say, 'Sufficient for me is Allah; there is no deity except Him. Upon Him I have relied, and He is the Lord of the Great Throne,'" Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, will suffice him from what concerns him of the matter of his Hereafter [akhirah], whether he was truthful or lying.
